body:
@n3nash 
1. Right now the parallelism is set to 1( Kafka partition is 1).  The average workload is 2000rps. 
2. I want to keep the output file size same as the hdfs block size.(256MB). What's the recommended size in production?
3. I prefer having small number of small files.
Hi, Can you clarify how appends are happening to GCS? Is it more of a concat or the file is recreated everytime (Given GCS does not provide update)?

@smalltimecharlie : I have not tried or hear anyone try with that setup  but would be happy to take in code/config changes that helps fixes the demo in your setup.  Not sure If I understood your message completely : Is the environment variable setup properly ? You might also want to see if there are any limitations with docker mounting  on your setup ?

Hudi does support composite primary keys. The Key generation is a pluggable component in Hudi.  By default, Hudi uses SimpleKeyGenerator (https://github.com/uber/hudi/blob/master/hoodie-spark/src/main/java/com/uber/hoodie/SimpleKeyGenerator.java) which uses the config (RECORDKEY_FIELD_OPT_KEY) to pick a single primary key.  

You can simply configure your own implementation of KeyGenerator using the configuration - hoodie.datasource.write.keygenerator.class and implement the getKey() method which takes in a row in Avro format and returns  a HoodieKey. HoodieKey is a combination of a row-key and partition-path.  Hoodie expects the key to be a string. So, you can just concatenate all the fields of the composite field.

Is it the case that every update/append to delta file creates a new file? 

And does the merge of the delta file handled by the compactor itself?

Your latency would be bound by amount of time it takes to merge the parquet file. 256MB files may take couple minutes (again depends on schema complexity etc that are parquet specific).. I would just first benchmark in batch with large paralellism, see the latency we get and move from there..

I understand what you are getting at. Do you think access control mechanisms on the underlying storage don't do enough to prevent external/unauthorized access? Of course, this proposal is still valid if you are concerned about authorized users with malicious intent. 

In terms of a full design for hoodie, we also need to take into account cleaning process, which deletes older files. And how each commit affects the partition hash. 

Can you expand on your use-case bit more so we can understand the requirements better?

From quickstart 

```
To work with older version of Hive (pre Hive-1.2.1), use

$ mvn clean install -DskipTests -DskipITs -Dhive11
```

hoodie.table.name=c_upload_code

@louisliu318 : THanks for filing this ticket. Yes, with Hive-1.2.1, the maven profile is hive12 (default). When I tested similar setup, I did not encounter this issue. This is caused by shading some of hive jars and including them in the bundle (bit of a magic by trial and error).  

It is not clear from your comment if you solved this by disabling shading ?  

Can you also try shading hive-metastore jar. Add this relocation in the shading section of pom.xml of hoodie-spark -
                <relocation>
                  <pattern>org.apache.hadoop.hive.metastore.</pattern>
                  <shadedPattern>com.uber.hoodie.org.apache.hadoop_hive.metastore.</shadedPattern>
                </relocation>

Let me know if this solves the problem.

@vinothchandar
I found that 
https://github.com/databricks/spark-avro/pull/291#issue-212513531
newest `databricks/spark-avro` just support avro 1.7, and timestamp/decimal only cast to long and string, and not support LogicalType.

In spark2.4, avro can be upgraded to 1.8.2.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-24771
and this problem can be solved.

I think there are two ways to try. Upgrade spark and don't use `databricks/spark-avro` or Replace avro to parquet basic api (like `org.apache.parquet.hadoop.ParquetWriter`) to write parquet.

It is another layer of protection. There are multiple layers in the security world, for example, authZ, authN, encryption, audit, and integrity. Sometimes there are some overlaps between them but mostly they complement each other.  Access control and data integrity should complement each other. For example, what if hackers break through the access control system or some storage might not turn on access control, or some access control systems might not be that fine grind etc. 

Deleting older files should be considered as an update of a given partition. The partition hash and table hash will be recalculated. 

How about I open this issue as tracking purpose only for now? I can get back to you in maybe several months as I have to deliver a higher priority project.

I solved the problem by comment out the relocations in the shading section of pom.xml of hoodie-spark -
.

Ideally we need to test this across all hive versions before making a call ... The hive jar versioning is very sensitive and changes made for one version often end up causing side effects for others

```
val spark = SparkSession.builder
      .master("yarn")
//      .config("spark.hadoop.fs.%s.impl.disable.cache", true)
      .config("spark.hadoop.fs.hdfs.impl.disable.cache", true)
```

@vinothchandar
I have found the solution. 
In `VIEW_TYPE_READ_OPTIMIZED_OPT_VAL` and `VIEW_TYPE_INCREMENTAL_OPT_VAL`, the path reading data is different.
`VIEW_TYPE_READ_OPTIMIZED_OPT_VAL` path is `/tmp/cloud2_code/c_upload_code/*/*/*/*`, `VIEW_TYPE_INCREMENTAL_OPT_VAL` path is `/tmp/cloud2_code/c_upload_code`. 
I think this issue can be closed.
By the way, why not merge into one expression?
Let me know if anything else is required to get this one landed

You can not preserve the type without changing the source code. You can check `HoodieSparkSqlWriter` -> `val schema = AvroConversionUtils.convertStructTypeToAvroSchema(df.schema, structName, nameSpace)` which used `spark-avro` package.

@bvaradar also brought this up. I am open to suggestions on this. The incremental read is a bit different than the read_optimized view in the sense, the path globs have no meaning. I had it this way to avoid confusion for users who may pass in a globbed path and then be handed records from partitions not in the glob. for e.g: even if you pass `/path/to/dataset/2018/12/*`, if your incremental reading range has data for 2018/11, it will return it to you right. 

How about handling this case more gracefully and throwing an error if the path passed to incremental query does not contain the `.hoodie` timeline folder or sth?
Yeah. I am a little hesistant to disable fs caching for this. We will prioritize this in jan.

nice catch. I actually thought about that initially and kept it (true, true) to avoid new users passing in duplicates to insert and getting confused about finding duplicates in the dataset. 

May be better docs is the way to go, rather than shuffling unnecessarily.. Happy to take a PR for this. @cdmikechen

Thanks for the reply.
So there is no support for saving Date or TimeStamp type in hudi?

PFB the datatype in Dataset before writing to hudi and after reading the data from hudi

Field --- date_last_cr_cust

*******Before saving ******

`scala> data_to_be_written.select("date_last_cr_cust").printSchema`

root
 |-- date_last_cr_cust: **date** (nullable = true)




******When the saved data is read from HDFS********

```
 spark.read.format("com.uber.hoodie").load("/apps/hive/warehouse/hoodie_full_account/KI0010200/*")
 .select("date_last_cr_cust").
  printSchema
```

root
 |-- date_last_cr_cust: **long** (nullable = true)
@vinothchandar OK. I will do it in a few days.
It seems that if the JavaRDD<HoodieRecord> are empty, then syncing to hive caused the problem. Skip if the JavaRDD<HoodieRecord> are empty, can resolve the problem.

By the way, In parquet 1.8 or earlier, it doesn't have date type. It just has int96(nanotime type) and stores as bytes.
If you want a long type date, you can use `getTime()` to save a long, and read by using timestamp function to trans to timestamp type(build like this `optional int64 timestamp (TIMESTAMP_MILLIS);`).
@n3nash any ideas?

Yeah, basically I introduced a new method in the timeline for allCommit and changed the existing one to allCommits. So, the changes you see across the files are just as a result of rename of the method. The new method is only used in the cleaner. Hope that helps
This is my fault. I give a partiontionFiled in hiveSyncConfig.

@louisliu318 It seems like the error is what you pasted above `java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Could not find any data file written for commit`. Do you see any parquet files getting created as part of this commit ?
@n3nash Sorry, I forgot to check that.  Before writing data, first check if the data is empty. If it's empty, skip; else write it. Then the problem went away.
Furthermore, If hudi upgrade to spark2.4, we can delete `spark-avro`'s lib and use spark's avro package(self contained) directly.

The

>  AvroConversionUtils.scala 

can be edited to manage the datatypes/values

We infact already did some of this, since we could not access few methods inside `spark-avro`. Happy to work together on this. If you can create a UnitTest that breaks as it is on hudi master and push it to a branch, then we can start iterating towards a solution..

@sidnakoppa ,  please follow #547 .. We can follow up there, with all the great analysis @cdmikechen has done already.. 

Separately, I recommend upgrading to Hive 2.x as much as possible. Speaking from experience at Uber, we had to deal with so many issues on Hive 1.x around schema evolution/data types, since parquet support was pretty raw back then... Is this something that's feasible for you? (all cloud stores for e.g, spin up Hive 2.x by default)

I will take a pass at the code diff...

Some thoughts on the larger issue you brought up. I dont think backing up the dataset is purely for rolling back to a good previous state.. Users could consider backing up even for disaster recovery purposes.. So lets keep that out for now. 

On rollbacks, 

- I think we should make the distinction between rollback (an uncommitted write) vs restore (which is what force rolling back a commit does)
- restore must be in a separate admin client
- we can continue supporting rollback as a way for marking some blocks as invalid in the logs. 

Nested rollbacks is a different thing. we can use this PR to talk about that

Hi Balaji, 

I'm happy to close this ticket if your happy. In the end I gave up with windows docker and just ran it in an ubuntu VM and all worked fine. 

I think the issue was with the way windows docker manages volumes being incompatible with creating them from docker compose scripts. 

Might be worth adding a note to this effect on the setup guide so others don't attempt the same as me!
addressed comments
Created new PR : https://github.com/uber/hudi/pull/551

Which parameter controls the parquet file size? I had set the following parameter but not working. There are lots of files with size 1.x MB after I bulk insert into hoodie table.

Other than the parameters that you have listed, bulkInsert parallelism (hoodie.bulkinsert.shuffle.parallelism) configuration also plays an important role in determining the number of files created due to bulkInsert. The default parallelism is set to 1500. If your dataset is not big enough for the default parallelism, please set it to a lower value.

@louisliu318 

Those are the right configs to use for turning on SMALL_FILE corrections.
`.option(HoodieCompactionConfig.PARQUET_SMALL_FILE_LIMIT_BYTES, 128 * 1024 * 1024)`

It may be just that at some point there were a lot of small files created and now they are slowly getting corrected depending on how many inserts you have. Can you notice other files which are closer to 128MB ?

As @bvaradar pointed out, you can always lower your parallelism. Although, by doing that you may end up with a larger execution time for that stage.
